content: 38 Therefore indeed, if Demetrius and the craftsmen with him have a word against anyone, the courts are being conducted and there are proconsuls; let them accuse one another.

title: Acts 19:39
content: 39 But if you seek anything about other matters, it will be settled in the regular assembly.

title: Acts 19:40
content: 40 For indeed we are in danger of being accused of rioting concerning the today, there being no cause about which we will be able to give an account concerning this disorder.”

title: Acts 19:41
content: 41 And having said these things, he dismissed the assembly.

title: Acts 20:1
content: 1 And after the uproar had ended, Paul, having summoned the disciples and encouraged them, saying farewell, departed to go to Macedonia.

title: Acts 20:2
content: 2 And having gone through those regions and having exhorted them with many a word, he came to Greece.

title: Acts 20:3
content: 3 And having stayed three months there, a plot by the Jews happening against him being about to sail to Syria, it happened that he returned of a resolution through Macedonia.

title: Acts 20:4
content: 4 And Sopater of Pyrrhus, a Berean, and Aristarchus and Secundus of the Thessalonians, and Gaius, a Derbean, and Timothy and Tychicus and Trophimus, Asians, were accompanying him.

title: Acts 20:5
content: 5 But they, having gone ahead, were waiting for us at Troas.

title: Acts 20:6
content: 6 And we sailed away from Philippi after the days of Unleavened Bread, and in five days we came to them in Troas, where we stayed for seven days.

title: Acts 20:7
content: 7 And on the first of the week, we having been gathered together to break bread, Paul was speaking with them. Being about to depart the next day, he was thus continuing the word until midnight.

title: Acts 20:8
content: 8 And many lamps were in the upper room where we were gathered together.

title: Acts 20:9
content: 9 And a certain young man, Eutychus by name, sitting on the window, being overcome by a deep sleep, Paul speaking even longer, having been overcome by sleep, he fell down from the third story and was picked up dead.

title: Acts 20:10
content: 10 But Paul, going down, stretched out on him and, having embraced him, said, “Do not be troubled, for his life is in him.”

title: Acts 20:11
content: 11 And having gone up and having broken bread and having tasted, and having conversed for much {time} until dawn, thus he left.

title: Acts 20:12
content: 12 But they brought the boy alive and were comforted not moderately.

title: Acts 20:13
content: 13 Then we, having gone ahead to the ship, sailed away to Assos, intending to take Paul on board there, for thus he had arranged, intending to go on foot himself.

title: Acts 20:14
content: 14 And when he met us at Assos, taking him on board, we went to Mitylene.

title: Acts 20:15
content: 15 And having sailed from there, we came down on the next day opposite Chios, and on the other day, we arrived at Samos, and on the following day, we came to Miletus.

title: Acts 20:16
content: 16 For Paul had decided to sail past Ephesus, so that it would not happen to him to lose time in Asia, for he was hurrying, if it might be possible for him, to be in Jerusalem for the day of Pentecost.

title: Acts 20:17
content: 17 And from Miletus, sending to Ephesus, he summoned the elders of the church.

title: Acts 20:18
content: 18 And when they came to him, he said to them, “You know, from the first day from which I set foot in Asia, how I was with you the whole time,

title: Acts 20:19
content: 19 serving the Lord with all humility and tears and trials happening to me in the plots of the Jews,

title: Acts 20:20
content: 20 how I withheld nothing being useful in order not to declare it to you, and I taught you in public and by houses,

title: Acts 20:21
content: 21 testifying to both Jews and Greeks repentance toward God and faith in our Lord Jesus.

title: Acts 20:22
content: 22 And now, behold, I am going to Jerusalem, having been bound by the Spirit, not knowing the things that will happen to me in her,

title: Acts 20:23
content: 23 except that the Holy Spirit testifies to me by city, saying that chains and afflictions await me.

title: Acts 20:24
content: 24 But of no word do I consider my life valuable to myself, so as to finish my race and the ministry that I received from the Lord Jesus, to attest the gospel of the grace of God.

title: Acts 20:25
content: 25 And now, behold, I know that you all, among whom I went about proclaiming the kingdom, will see my face no more.

title: Acts 20:26
content: 26 Therefore I testify to you in the today day that I am innocent from the blood of all.

title: Acts 20:27
content: 27 For I did not hold back in order not to declare to you all the counsel of God.

title: Acts 20:28
content: 28 Guard yourselves and all the flock among which the Holy Spirit has made you overseers to shepherd the church of God, which he obtained through his own blood.

title: Acts 20:29
content: 29 I know that after my departure, vicious wolves will come in among you, not sparing the flock.

title: Acts 20:30
content: 30 Even from you yourselves, men will arise speaking perverted things in order to draw away the disciples after them.

title: Acts 20:31
content: 31 So be alert, remembering that for three years I did not stop admonishing each one with tears night and day.

title: Acts 20:32
content: 32 And now I am entrusting you to God and to the word of his grace being able to build you up and to give you the inheritance among all the ones having been sanctified.

title: Acts 20:33
content: 33 I coveted the silver or gold or clothing of no one.

title: Acts 20:34
content: 34 You yourselves know that these hands ministered to my needs and to the ones being with me.

title: Acts 20:35
content: 35 I showed you all things, that it is necessary, working hard in this way, to take hold of the ones being weak and to remember the words of the Lord Jesus, that he himself said, ‘It is more blessed to give than to receive.’”

title: Acts 20:36
content: 36 And having said these things, bowing his knees, he prayed with them all.

title: Acts 20:37
content: 37 But much weeping happened among them all, and falling upon the neck of Paul, they were kissing him,

title: Acts 20:38
content: 38 grieving mostly at the word that he had spoken, that they were going to see his face no more. Then they escorted him to the ship.

title: Acts 21:1
content: 1 And it happened that as we put to sea, having been parted from them, running a straight course, we came to Cos, and on the next day to Rhodes, and from there to Patara.

title: Acts 21:2
content: 2 And finding a ship crossing over to Phoenicia, going aboard, we put to sea.

title: Acts 21:3
content: 3 And having sighted Cyprus and having left it behind on the port side, we sailed to Syria and came down to Tyre, for there the ship was unloading {its} cargo.

title: Acts 21:4
content: 4 And having found the disciples, we stayed there seven days, who were saying to Paul through the Spirit not to set foot in Jerusalem.

title: Acts 21:5
content: 5 And when it happened that we had finished the days, having gone out, we were proceeding, everyone accompanying us with wives and children as far as outside the city, and having put down {our} knees on the shore {and} having prayed,

title: Acts 21:6
content: 6 we said farewell to each other and we went up into the ship and those returned to {their} own homes,

title: Acts 21:7
content: 7 but we, having finished the voyage from Tyre, came down to Ptolemais, and having greeted the brothers, we stayed with them for one day.

title: Acts 21:8
content: 8 And on the next day, having departed, we went to Caesarea and, entering into the house of Philip the Evangelist, who was from the Seven, we stayed with him.

title: Acts 21:9
content: 9 Now to this one were four daughters, virgins, prophesying.

title: Acts 21:10
content: 10 And as we stayed for many days, a certain prophet, Agabus by name, came down from Judea.

title: Acts 21:11
content: 11 And having come to us and having taken the belt of Paul, having bound his own feet and hands, he said, “The Holy Spirit says these things: ‘Thus will the Jews in Jerusalem bind the man of whom is this belt, and they will deliver him into the hands of the Gentiles.’”

title: Acts 21:12
content: 12 And when we heard these things, both we and the locals were urging him not to go up to Jerusalem.

title: Acts 21:13
content: 13 Then Paul answered, “What are you doing, weeping and breaking my heart? For I am ready not only to be bound but also to die in Jerusalem for the name of the Lord Jesus.”

title: Acts 21:14
content: 14 And as he was not being persuaded, we kept quiet, saying, “Let the will of the Lord happen.”

title: Acts 21:15
content: 15 And after these days, having equipped ourselves, we went up to Jerusalem.

title: Acts 21:16
content: 16 And {some} of the disciples from Caesarea also came with us, bringing us to Mnason, a certain Cypriot, an early disciple, with whom we would be hosted.

title: Acts 21:17
content: 17 And when we had arrived in Jerusalem, the brothers welcomed us gladly.

title: Acts 21:18
content: 18 And on the next day Paul went in with us to James, and all the elders were present.

title: Acts 21:19
content: 19 And having greeted them, he was declaring, one by one, each of the things God had done among the Gentiles through his ministry.

title: Acts 21:20
content: 20 And having heard it, they were glorifying God, and they said to him, “You see, brother, how many myriads of those having believed there are among the Jews, and they are all zealous for the law.

title: Acts 21:21
content: 21 And they have been told about you that you teach all the Jews among the Gentiles apostasy from Moses, telling them not to circumcise {their} children, nor to walk in the customs.

title: Acts 21:22
content: 22 What therefore is it? They will certainly hear that you have come.

title: Acts 21:23
content: 23 So do this that we say to you. Four men are with us having a vow from themselves.

title: Acts 21:24
content: 24 Taking these men, be purified with them and pay the expenses for them, so that they will shear {their} heads, and then everyone will know that there is nothing in the things they have been told about you, but that you conform, also keeping the law yourself.

title: Acts 21:25
content: 25 But concerning the Gentiles having believed, having judged, we sent that they should guard the idol-sacrificed and blood and the strangled and sexual immorality.”

title: Acts 21:26
content: 26 Then Paul, having taken the men, having been purified with them the next day, was going into the temple declaring the fulfillment of the days of purification, until the offering was offered for each one of them.

title: Acts 21:27
content: 27 But when the seven days were about to be finished, the Jews from Asia, seeing Paul in the temple, were agitating the whole crowd, and they laid {their} hands on him,

title: Acts 21:28
content: 28 shouting, “Men, Israelites, help! This is the man teaching all everywhere against the people and the law and this place. And he has even both brought Greeks into the temple and has defiled this holy place.”

title: Acts 21:29
content: 29 For they had previously seen Trophimus the Ephesian with him in the city, whom they were thinking that Paul had brought into the temple.

title: Acts 21:30
content: 30 And the whole city was excited, and a mob of the people happened, and having taken hold of Paul, they were dragging him outside of the temple, and immediately the doors were shut.

title: Acts 21:31
content: 31 And as they were seeking to kill him, a report came up to the chiliarch of the cohort that all Jerusalem was agitated,

title: Acts 21:32
content: 32 who, immediately taking soldiers and centurions, ran down to them. And they, seeing the chiliarch and the soldiers, stopped beating Paul.

title: Acts 21:33
content: 33 Then, approaching, the commander took hold of him and commanded him to be bound with two chains, and he was asking who he might be and what he had done.

title: Acts 21:34
content: 34 But different ones in the crowd were shouting different things, and he, not being able to learn the certain because of the noise, ordered him to be brought into the fortress.

title: Acts 21:35
content: 35 But when he came to the steps, it happened that he was carried by the soldiers because of the violence of the crowd.

title: Acts 21:36
content: 36 For the multitude of the people was following, shouting, “Take him away!”

title: Acts 21:37
content: 37 And being about to be brought into the fortress, Paul says to the chiliarch, “If it is permitted for me to say something to you?” But he said, “Do you know Greek?

title: Acts 21:38
content: 38 Then are you not the Egyptian having revolted before these days and having led 4,000 men of the Sicarii into the wilderness?”

title: Acts 21:39
content: 39 But Paul said, “I am a Jewish man, a Tarsian of Cilicia, a citizen of a not undistinguished city. And I ask of you, allow me to speak to the people.”

title: Acts 21:40
content: 40 And when he allowed, Paul, standing on the steps, motioned with {his} hand to the people. And when a deep silence happened, he spoke in the Hebrew language, saying,

title: Acts 22:1
content: 1 “Men, brothers and fathers, hear my defense to you now.”

title: Acts 22:2
content: 2 And when they heard that he was speaking to them in the Hebrew language, they granted more quietness. And he said,

title: Acts 22:3
content: 3 “I am a Jewish man, born in Tarsus of Cilicia but educated in this city at the feet of Gamaliel, instructed according to the strictness of the law of our fathers, being zealous for God, as you all are today,

title: Acts 22:4
content: 4 who persecuted this Way unto death, binding and delivering to prison both men and women,

title: Acts 22:5
content: 5 as also the high priest testifies for me, and all the elderhood, from whom also having received letters to the brothers, I was traveling to Damascus, going to bring back bound to Jerusalem even those being there so that they might be punished.

title: Acts 22:6
content: 6 And it happened to me that, traveling and nearing Damascus about noon, suddenly a great light from heaven shone around me.

title: Acts 22:7
content: 7 And I fell to the ground and I heard a voice saying to me, ‘Saul, Saul, why are you persecuting me?’

title: Acts 22:8
content: 8 And I answered, ‘Who are you, Lord?’ And he said to me, ‘I am Jesus the Nazarene, whom you are persecuting.’

title: Acts 22:9
content: 9 Now the ones being with me saw the light, but they did not hear the voice of the one speaking to me.

title: Acts 22:10
content: 10 But I said, ‘What should I do, Lord?’ And the Lord said to me, ‘Arising, go into Damascus, and there it will be told to you about all that has been appointed to you to do.’

title: Acts 22:11
content: 11 And as I was not seeing clearly because of the glory of that light, being led by the hand by the ones being with me, I came into Damascus.

title: Acts 22:12
content: 12 And Ananias, a certain devout man according to the law, being attested by all the Jews living there,

title: Acts 22:13
content: 13 came to me and, standing by me, said to me, ‘Saul, brother, look up.’ And in the same hour I looked up to him.

title: Acts 22:14
content: 14 And he said, ‘The God of our fathers appointed you to know his will and to see the Righteous One and to hear the voice from his mouth,

title: Acts 22:15
content: 15 for you will be a witness for him to all men of what you have seen and heard.

title: Acts 22:16
content: 16 And now, why are you delaying? Arising, be baptized and wash away your sins, calling on his name.’

title: Acts 22:17
content: 17 And it happened to me that, having returned to Jerusalem, and as I was praying in the temple, I became in a trance.

title: Acts 22:18
content: 18 And I saw him saying to me, ‘Hurry and go away in haste from Jerusalem, because they will not accept your testimony about me.’

title: Acts 22:19
content: 19 And I said, ‘Lord, they themselves know that I was imprisoning and beating by synagogues the ones believing in you.

title: Acts 22:20
content: 20 And when the blood of Stephen your witness was spilled, I myself was also standing by and agreeing and guarding the outer garments of the ones killing him.’

title: Acts 22:21
content: 21 But he said to me, ‘Go, because I will send you far away to the Gentiles.’”

title: Acts 22:22
content: 22 And they were listening to him until this word, and they lifted up their voice, saying, “Remove such a one from the earth, for it was not right for him to live.”

title: Acts 22:23
content: 23 And as they were shouting and casting off {their} outer garments, and throwing dust into the air,

title: Acts 22:24
content: 24 the chiliarch ordered him to be brought into the fortress, commanding him to be examined by scourges, so that he might know for what reason they were shouting thus against him.

title: Acts 22:25
content: 25 But when they stretched him out for the whips, Paul said to the centurion standing by, “If it is lawful for you to scourge a man Roman and uncondemned?”

title: Acts 22:26
content: 26 And hearing this. the centurion, going to the chiliarch, reported, saying, “What are you about to do? For this man is a Roman.”

title: Acts 22:27
content: 27 So coming, the chiliarch said to him, “Tell me, are you a Roman?” And he said, “Yes.”

title: Acts 22:28
content: 28 And the commander answered, “I bought this citizenship with a large sum of money.” But Paul said, “But I indeed was born.”

title: Acts 22:29
content: 29 Then the ones being about to examine him drew back from him immediately, and the chiliarch also was afraid, having learned that he was a Roman, because indeed he had bound him.

title: Acts 22:30
content: 30 And on the next day, wanting to know the certain, why he was being accused by the Jews, he released him and commanded the chief priests and all the Sanhedrin to assemble. And having brought down Paul, he placed him among them.

title: Acts 23:1
content: 1 And looking intently at the Sanhedrin, Paul said, “Men, brothers, I have conducted myself toward God in all good conscience up to this day.”

title: Acts 23:2
content: 2 But Ananias the high priest commanded the ones standing by him to strike his mouth.

title: Acts 23:3
content: 3 Then Paul said to him, “God is about to strike you, you whitewashed wall! And do you sit judging me by the law and, acting contrary to the law, command me to be struck?”

title: Acts 23:4
content: 4 But the ones standing by said, “Are you insulting the high priest of God?”

title: Acts 23:5
content: 5 And Paul said, “I did not know, brothers, that he was the high priest. For it is written, ‘You shall not speak evil of a ruler of your people.’”

title: Acts 23:6
content: 6 Then Paul, realizing that one part was Sadducees and the other Pharisees, shouted in the Sanhedrin, “Men, brothers, I am a Pharisee, a son of Pharisees; concerning the hope and resurrection of the dead I am being judged.”

title: Acts 23:7
content: 7 And when he said this, an argument happened between the Pharisees and Sadducees, and the multitude was divided.

title: Acts 23:8
content: 8 For Sadducees say there is no resurrection, nor angels or spirits, but Pharisees confess both.

title: Acts 23:9
content: 9 So a great uproar happened, and arising, some of the scribes of the party of the Pharisees were contending, saying, “We find nothing evil in this man. And if a spirit spoke to him, or an angel …”

title: Acts 23:10
content: 10 And when a great argument happened, the chiliarch, fearing lest Paul be torn apart by them, ordered the soldiers to go down to seize him from the midst of them and to bring him into the fortress.

title: Acts 23:11
content: 11 But on the following night, the Lord, having stood beside him, said, “Be courageous, for as you have attested the things concerning me in Jerusalem, so it is necessary also for you to testify in Rome.”

title: Acts 23:12
content: 12 And when day came, the Jews, making a conspiracy, cursed themselves, saying neither to eat nor to drink until they had killed Paul.

title: Acts 23:13
content: 13 And the ones having made this conspiracy were more than 40,

title: Acts 23:14
content: 14 who, going to the chief priests and the elders, said, “We have cursed ourselves with a curse, to eat nothing until we have killed Paul.

title: Acts 23:15
content: 15 Now, therefore, you, with the Sanhedrin, appear to the chiliarch as if you are going to examine more thoroughly the things concerning him, so that he may bring him down to you. But we are ready to kill him before he arrives.”

title: Acts 23:16
content: 16 But hearing the ambush, the son of the sister of Paul, going and entering into the fortress, reported it to Paul.

title: Acts 23:17
content: 17 So calling one of the centurions, Paul said, “Take this young man to the chiliarch, for he has something to report to him.”

title: Acts 23:18
content: 18 So taking him, he brought him to the chiliarch and says, “The prisoner, Paul, having summoned me, asked me to bring to you this young man having something to say to you.”

title: Acts 23:19
content: 19 So the chiliarch, taking hold of his hand and withdrawing, was asking him in private, “What is it that you have to report to me?”

title: Acts 23:20
content: 20 So he said, “The Jews have agreed to ask you that tomorrow you might bring Paul down to the Sanhedrin, as if they were going to investigate something about him more thoroughly.

title: Acts 23:21
content: 21 Therefore may you not be persuaded by them, because from them more than 40 men wait in ambush for him, who have cursed themselves neither to eat nor to drink until they have killed him. Even now they are ready, waiting for the promise from you.”

title: Acts 23:22
content: 22 So the chiliarch dismissed the young man, commanding him to tell no one that “you have reported these things to me.”

title: Acts 23:23
content: 23 And summoning a certain two of the centurions, he said, “Prepare 200 soldiers and 70 horsemen and 200 spearmen so that they might go to Caesarea at the third hour of the night,”

title: Acts 23:24
content: 24 and to provide animals so that, having set Paul on them, they may bring him safely to Felix the governor,

title: Acts 23:25
content: 25 writing a letter, having this form:

title: Acts 23:26
content: 26 “Claudius Lysias to the most excellent Governor Felix: Greetings.

title: Acts 23:27
content: 27 This man, having been seized by the Jews and about to be killed by them, coming with a detachment of soldiers, I rescued, having learned that he was a Roman.

title: Acts 23:28
content: 28 And wanting to know the charge with which they were accusing him, I took him down to their Sanhedrin,

title: Acts 23:29
content: 29 whom I found being accused about questions of their law but having no accusation worthy of death or chains.

title: Acts 23:30
content: 30 And when a plot that was to be against the man was revealed to me, immediately I sent him to you, also commanding the accusers to speak against him to you.”

title: Acts 23:31
content: 31 So the soldiers, according to the thing having been commanded to them, taking Paul, brought him by night to Antipatris.

title: Acts 23:32
content: 32 And on the next day they returned to the fortress, allowing the horsemen to go away with him,

title: Acts 23:33
content: 33 who, entering into Caesarea and delivering the letter to the governor, also presented Paul to him.

title: Acts 23:34
content: 34 And having read the letter and having asked what province he was from and having learned that {he was} from Cilicia,

title: Acts 23:35
content: 35 he said, “I will hear you fully when your accusers may also come,” commanding him to be guarded in the palace of Herod.

title: Acts 24:1
content: 1 And after five days, Ananias, the high priest, with certain elders and a certain orator, Tertullus, came down, who appeared to the governor against Paul.

title: Acts 24:2
content: 2 And when he had been summoned, Tertullus began to accuse him, saying, “As we are obtaining great peace through you, and as reforms are happening for this people through your foresight

title: Acts 24:3
content: 3 both in every way and everywhere, we receive {these things}, most excellent Felix, with all thankfulness.

title: Acts 24:4
content: 4 But so that I may not detain you further, I ask you to listen to us briefly in your fairness.

title: Acts 24:5
content: 5 For having found this man a pest and one inciting rebellion among all the Jews throughout the world and a leader of the sect of the Nazarenes,

title: Acts 24:6
content: 6 who even tried to desecrate the temple, whom also we arrested; [and we wanted to judge him according to our law,

title: Acts 24:7
content: 7 but Lysias, the chiliarch, coming with much force, took him away from our hands,

title: Acts 24:8
content: 8 commanding his accusers to come to you;] from whom, having inquired about all these things, you yourself will be able to learn of what things we are accusing him.”

title: Acts 24:9
content: 9 And the Jews also agreed, affirming these things to be thus.

title: Acts 24:10
content: 10 And Paul answered, the governor having motioned for him to speak, “Knowing you to have been a judge to this nation for many years, I gladly make my defense about the things concerning me,

title: Acts 24:11
content: 11 you being able to learn that it is not more than 12 days for me from when I went up to Jerusalem to worship,

title: Acts 24:12
content: 12 and they found me neither in the temple arguing with anyone, nor causing a rebellion of the crowd, not in the synagogues, and not throughout the city,

title: Acts 24:13
content: 13 and they are not able to prove {the things} to you about which they are now accusing me.

title: Acts 24:14
content: 14 But I confess this to you, that according to the Way that they call a sect, thus I serve the fathers’ God, being faithful to all the things according to the law and the things written in the Prophets,

title: Acts 24:15
content: 15 having a hope in God that these themselves also accept, that there is going to be a resurrection of both the righteous and the unrighteous.

title: Acts 24:16
content: 16 In this I myself also strive to have a blameless conscience before God and men continually.

title: Acts 24:17
content: 17 Now after many years I came to my nation bringing alms and offerings,

title: Acts 24:18
content: 18 in which they found me in the temple, having been cleansed, not with a crowd, nor with an uproar.

title: Acts 24:19
content: 19 But certain Jews from Asia—who ought to be present before you and make accusations if they have anything against me.

title: Acts 24:20
content: 20 Or let these themselves say what wrong they found when I stood before the Sanhedrin,

title: Acts 24:21
content: 21 {other} than regarding this one utterance that I shouted out standing among them, ‘Concerning the resurrection of the dead I am being judged by you today!’”

title: Acts 24:22
content: 22 Then Felix, knowing more accurately the things concerning the Way, adjourned them, saying, “When Lysias the chiliarch may come down, I will decide the things concerning you,”

title: Acts 24:23
content: 23 commanding the centurion to guard him and for him to have freedom and to forbid none of his own to minister to him.

title: Acts 24:24
content: 24 But after some days Felix, returning with Drusilla, his own wife, being a Jewess, summoned Paul and heard him concerning the faith in Christ Jesus.

title: Acts 24:25
content: 25 But as he was reasoning about righteousness and self-control and the coming judgment, Felix, becoming frightened, answered, “Go away for now, but having found time, I will summon you,”

title: Acts 24:26
content: 26 also hoping at the same time that money would be given to him by Paul, and therefore summoning him often, he was speaking with him.

title: Acts 24:27
content: 27 But two years being fulfilled, Felix received a successor, Porcius Festus, and wanting to gain favor with the Jews, Felix left Paul bound.

title: Acts 25:1
content: 1 Now Festus, having set foot in the province, went up from Caesarea to Jerusalem after three days.

title: Acts 25:2
content: 2 And the chief priests and the first of the Jews appeared to him against Paul, and they were begging him,

title: Acts 25:3
content: 3 requesting a favor against him, that he might summon him to Jerusalem, making an ambush to kill him along the way.

title: Acts 25:4
content: 4 Then Festus answered that Paul was being held at Caesarea but that he himself was about to depart soon.

title: Acts 25:5
content: 5 He said, “Therefore, the powerful among you, having come down together, if there is something wrong with the man, let them accuse him.”

title: Acts 25:6
content: 6 And having stayed with them not more than eight or ten days, he went down to Caesarea. On the next day, having sat in the judgment seat, he commanded Paul to be brought.

title: Acts 25:7
content: 7 And when he had come, the Jews having come down from Jerusalem stood around him, bringing many and serious charges that they were not able to prove,

title: Acts 25:8
content: 8 as Paul was saying in defense, “Neither against the law of the Jews, nor against the temple, nor against Caesar have I committed any sin.”

title: Acts 25:9
content: 9 But Festus, wanting to lay down a favor for the Jews, answering Paul, said, “Are you willing, having gone up to Jerusalem, to be judged before me there about these things?”

title: Acts 25:10
content: 10 But Paul said, “I am standing before the judgment seat of Caesar, where it is necessary for me to be judged. I have done no harm to the Jews, as you also know very well.

title: Acts 25:11
content: 11 Therefore, if I am doing harm and have done something worthy of death, I do not refuse to die. But if {the things} of which they are accusing me are nothing, no one is able to give me to them as a favor. I appeal to Caesar!”

title: Acts 25:12
content: 12 Then Festus, having spoken with the council, answered, “To Caesar you have appealed, to Caesar you will go!”

title: Acts 25:13
content: 13 Now after some days had passed, King Agrippa and Bernice, having come down to Caesarea, greeted Festus.

title: Acts 25:14
content: 14 And as they were staying there for many days, Festus presented to the king the things concerning Paul, saying, “A certain man has been left a prisoner by Felix,

title: Acts 25:15
content: 15 about whom, when I was in Jerusalem, the chief priests and the elders of the Jews appeared, requesting a judgment against him.

title: Acts 25:16
content: 16 to whom I replied that the custom of the Romans is not to give any man as a favor before the one being accused may have the accusers by face and receive an opportunity of a defense concerning the accusation.

title: Acts 25:17
content: 17 Therefore, when they had come together here, causing no delay, the next day, having sat in the judgment seat, I commanded the man to be brought,

title: Acts 25:18
content: 18 about whom the accusers, having stood up, brought no charge of the evils that I was expecting.

title: Acts 25:19
content: 19 Instead, they were having certain disputes with him about their own religion and about a certain Jesus, having died, whom Paul asserted to be alive.

title: Acts 25:20
content: 20 And I, doubting the investigation about these things, asked if he might be willing to go to Jerusalem and be judged there about these things.

title: Acts 25:21
content: 21 But when Paul appealed that he be kept for the decision of the August one, I commanded him to be kept until I might send him to Caesar.”

title: Acts 25:22
content: 22 And Agrippa {replied} to Festus, “I myself was also wanting to hear this man.” “Tomorrow,” he says, “you will hear him.”

title: Acts 25:23
content: 23 So on the next day, Agrippa and Bernice having come with much ceremony and having entered into the hall with both chiliarchs and men of distinction of the city, then, having been commanded by Festus, Paul was brought.

title: Acts 25:24
content: 24 And Festus said, “King Agrippa and all the men being present with us, you see this one concerning whom the whole multitude of the Jews petitioned me both in Jerusalem and here, shouting that he ought not to live any longer.

title: Acts 25:25
content: 25 But I learned that he had done nothing worthy of death. But this one himself having appealed to the August one, I decided to send him,

title: Acts 25:26
content: 26 about whom I do not have anything definite to write to the lord. Therefore I have brought him before you, and especially before you, King Agrippa, so that, the examination having happened, I might have something that I might write.

title: Acts 25:27
content: 27 For it seems unreasonable to me, sending a prisoner and not to signify the charges against him.”

title: Acts 26:1
content: 1 And Agrippa said to Paul, “It is permitted to you to speak about yourself.” Then Paul, stretching out {his} hand, was defending himself:

title: Acts 26:2
content: 2 “Concerning all the things of which I am accused by the Jews, King Agrippa, I consider myself blessed to be about to defend myself before you today,

title: Acts 26:3
content: 3 especially you being an expert in all the customs and controversies among the Jews. So I ask you to hear me patiently.

title: Acts 26:4
content: 4 Indeed, then, all the Jews know the manner of my life from my youth, having happened from the beginning in my nation and in Jerusalem,

title: Acts 26:5
content: 5 knowing me from the beginning, if they wished to testify, that according to the strictest sect of our religion I lived as a Pharisee.

title: Acts 26:6
content: 6 And now I stand here being judged because of hope of the promise made to our fathers by God,

title: Acts 26:7
content: 7 to which our 12 tribes hope to attain, serving in earnestness night and day, concerning which hope I am being accused by the Jews, O King.

title: Acts 26:8
content: 8 Why is it judged unbelievable among you if God raises the dead?

title: Acts 26:9
content: 9 Indeed, for myself, I thought it to be necessary to do many things opposed to the name of Jesus the Nazarene,

title: Acts 26:10
content: 10 which I did even in Jerusalem, and I even locked up many of the saints in prisons, having received authority from the chief priests, and when they were being executed, I cast my vote against them.

title: Acts 26:11
content: 11 And often punishing them in all the synagogues, I forced them to blaspheme, and being greatly enraged against them, I persecuted them even as far as to other cities,

title: Acts 26:12
content: 12 in which things, traveling to Damascus with authority and a commission from the chief priests,

title: Acts 26:13
content: 13 in the middle of the day, along the road, I saw, O King, a light from heaven, beyond the brightness of the sun, shining around me and the ones traveling with me.

title: Acts 26:14
content: 14 And when we all had fallen to the ground, I heard a voice speaking to me in the Hebrew language, ‘Saul, Saul, why are you persecuting me? It is hard for you to kick against a goad.’

title: Acts 26:15
content: 15 And I said, ‘Who are you, Lord?’ And the Lord said, ‘I am Jesus, whom you are persecuting.

title: Acts 26:16
content: 16 But get up and stand on your feet, because for this I have appeared to you, to appoint you a servant and a witness both of the things in which you have seen me and of the things in which I will be shown to you,

title: Acts 26:17
content: 17 rescuing you from the people and from the Gentiles, to whom I am sending you,

title: Acts 26:18
content: 18 to open their eyes to turn from darkness to light and from the authority of Satan to God, for them to receive forgiveness of sins and an inheritance among the ones having been sanctified by faith in me.’

title: Acts 26:19
content: 19 Therefore, King Agrippa, I was not disobedient to the heavenly vision,

title: Acts 26:20
content: 20 but first to the ones in Damascus and also in Jerusalem and the whole region of Judea and to the Gentiles I declared to repent and turn to God, doing deeds worthy of repentance.

title: Acts 26:21
content: 21 Because of these things, the Jews, having seized me in the temple, were trying to kill me.

title: Acts 26:22
content: 22 Therefore, having received help from God up to this day, I stand, testifying to both small and great, saying nothing except the things that both the prophets and Moses said were going to happen—

title: Acts 26:23
content: 23 if the Christ would be a sufferer, if he, the first from the resurrection of the dead, was going to proclaim light both to the people and to the Gentiles.”

title: Acts 26:24
content: 24 And as he was saying these things in his defense, Festus says in a loud voice, “Paul, you are insane! Great learning is turning you to insanity.”

title: Acts 26:25
content: 25 But Paul says, “I am not insane, most excellent Festus, but I am speaking words of truth and of sanity.

title: Acts 26:26
content: 26 For the king knows about these things—to whom indeed, speaking boldly, I am talking—for I am not persuaded at all that any of these things eludes him, for this has not been done in a corner.

title: Acts 26:27
content: 27 Do you believe the prophets, King Agrippa? I know that you believe.”

title: Acts 26:28
content: 28 But Agrippa said to Paul, “In little are you persuading me to make me a Christian?”

title: Acts 26:29
content: 29 But Paul replied, “I would wish to God, either in little or in much, that not only you but also all the ones hearing me today would become such as I also am—without these chains.”

title: Acts 26:30
content: 30 Then the king got up, and the governor and Bernice and the ones sitting with them,

title: Acts 26:31
content: 31 and having left, they were talking to one another, saying, “This man is not doing anything worthy of death or of chains.”

title: Acts 26:32
content: 32 And Agrippa said to Festus, “This man was able to have been released if he had not appealed to Caesar.”

title: Acts 27:1
content: 1 And when it was decided for us to sail to Italy, they were delivering both Paul and some other prisoners to a centurion, Julius by name, of the Augustan regiment.

title: Acts 27:2
content: 2 And having boarded a ship from Adramyttium being about to sail to places along Asia, we put to sea, Aristarchus, a Macedonian, a Thessalonian, being with us.

title: Acts 27:3
content: 3 And on the next day, we came down to Sidon, and Julius, treating Paul kindly, allowed him, going to {his} friends, to receive {their} care.

title: Acts 27:4
content: 4 And from there, having put to sea, we sailed under Cyprus because the winds were contrary.

title: Acts 27:5
content: 5 And having sailed across the sea along Cilicia and Pamphylia, we came down to Myra of Lycia.

title: Acts 27:6
content: 6 And there, the centurion having found an Alexandrian ship sailing to Italy, he put us on it.

title: Acts 27:7
content: 7 And sailing slowly for many days and having arrived with difficulty near Cnidus, the wind not permitting us further, we sailed along Crete opposite Salmone.

title: Acts 27:8
content: 8 And sailing along it with difficulty, we came to a certain place called Fair Havens, which was near the city of Lasea.

title: Acts 27:9
content: 9 But much time having passed, and the voyage already being dangerous because even the fast had already passed, Paul was warning them,

title: Acts 27:10
content: 10 saying to them, “Men, I see that the voyage is about to be with injury and much loss, not only of the cargo and the ship, but also of our lives.”

title: Acts 27:11
content: 11 But the centurion was being persuaded more by the pilot and by the captain than by the things being spoken by Paul.

title: Acts 27:12
content: 12 But the harbor being unsuitable for wintering, the majority gave counsel to sail from there, if somehow they might be able to come down to Phoenix, a harbor in Crete looking according to the southwest wind and according to the northwest wind, to winter there.

title: Acts 27:13
content: 13 And as a south wind was blowing gently, thinking to have obtained {their} purpose, having raised {the anchor}, they were sailing along close to Crete.

title: Acts 27:14
content: 14 But after not long, a tempestuous wind called Eurakylon rushed down from it.

title: Acts 27:15
content: 15 And the ship having been seized and not being able to face into the wind, having given way, we were driven along.

title: Acts 27:16
content: 16 But running under a certain island called Cauda, we were able with difficulty to become controllers of the lifeboat,

title: Acts 27:17
content: 17 which having hoisted up, they were using helps, undergirding the ship. And fearing lest they might fall into the Syrtis, lowering the gear, thus they were being driven along.

title: Acts 27:18
content: 18 But we being exceedingly storm-tossed, on the next day they were doing a jettison.

title: Acts 27:19
content: 19 And on the third day they threw the equipment of the ship {overboard} with their own hands.

title: Acts 27:20
content: 20 But neither sun nor stars appearing for many days, and no small storm lying upon us, all hope for us to be saved was finally being taken away.

title: Acts 27:21
content: 21 And as there had been much abstinence, then Paul, having stood up in the midst of them, said, “O men, it was indeed necessary, obeying me, not to put to sea from Crete and to avoid this damage and loss.

title: Acts 27:22
content: 22 But now I urge you to take courage, for there will be no loss of life among you, only of the ship.

title: Acts 27:23
content: 23 For this night an angel of the God whose I am and whom I serve stood beside me,

title: Acts 27:24
content: 24 saying, ‘Do not be afraid, Paul. It is necessary for you to stand before Caesar, and behold, God has graciously granted to you all the ones sailing with you.’

title: Acts 27:25
content: 25 Therefore take courage, men! For I trust in God that it will be thus, according to the way it was told to me.

title: Acts 27:26
content: 26 But it is necessary for us to fall upon some island.”

title: Acts 27:27
content: 27 And when the fourteenth night happened, as we were being driven about in the Hadria, around the middle of the night the sailors were suspecting some land to be approaching them.

title: Acts 27:28
content: 28 And taking soundings, they found 20 fathoms, but having gone a little farther and taking soundings again, they found 15 fathoms.

title: Acts 27:29
content: 29 And fearing lest we might fall upon a rugged place somewhere, having lowered four anchors from the stern, they were praying for day to come.

title: Acts 27:30
content: 30 But as the sailors were seeking to flee from the ship, and as they had lowered the lifeboat into the sea on a pretext as if intending to lower anchors from the bow,

title: Acts 27:31
content: 31 Paul said to the centurion and to the soldiers, “If these do not stay in the ship, you are not able to be saved.”

title: Acts 27:32
content: 32 Then the soldiers cut the ropes of the lifeboat and let it fall away.

title: Acts 27:33
content: 33 And until day was about to come, Paul was urging them all to take food, saying, “Anxiously waiting for a fourteenth day today, you are continuing fasting, having eaten nothing.

title: Acts 27:34
content: 34 Therefore, I urge you to take food, for this is for your salvation. For a hair from the head of none of you will perish.”

title: Acts 27:35
content: 35 And having said this and having taken bread, he gave thanks to God before everyone and, having broken bread, he began to eat.

title: Acts 27:36
content: 36 And they were all encouraged and took food themselves.

title: Acts 27:37
content: 37 Now we, all the souls in the ship, were 276.

title: Acts 27:38
content: 38 And having been satisfied with food, they were lightening the ship, throwing out the wheat into the sea.

title: Acts 27:39
content: 39 And when day came, they were not recognizing the land, but they were noticing a certain bay having a beach, onto which they were discussing whether they might be able to drive the ship.

title: Acts 27:40
content: 40 And having cut loose the anchors, they left them in the sea. At the same time, having loosened the bands of the rudders and having raised the topsail to the wind, they were heading to the beach.

title: Acts 27:41
content: 41 But having fallen into a place between two seas, the ship ran aground, and the bow of the ship, having stuck there, remained immovable, but the stern was being loosed by the violence.

title: Acts 27:42
content: 42 Now the plan of the soldiers was that they would kill the prisoners, lest any, swimming away, might escape.

title: Acts 27:43
content: 43 But the centurion, wanting to save Paul, stopped their plan, and he commanded the ones being able to swim to depart first to the land, jumping overboard,

title: Acts 27:44
content: 44 and the rest, some on planks, and some on certain things from the ship, and in this way it happened that all were brought safely to the land.

title: Acts 28:1
content: 1 And having been brought safely through, we then learned that the island was called Malta.

title: Acts 28:2
content: 2 And the barbarians were offering no ordinary benevolence to us, for, lighting a fire because of the impending rain and because of the cold, they welcomed us all.

title: Acts 28:3
content: 3 But when Paul had gathered a certain quantity of sticks and had placed them on the fire, a viper, coming out from the heat, seized his hand.

title: Acts 28:4
content: 4 And as the barbarians saw the creature hanging from his hand, they were saying to one another, “This man is certainly a murderer, whom, having been saved from the sea, Justice has not permitted to live.”

title: Acts 28:5
content: 5 Then he, shaking off the creature into the fire, suffered no harm.

title: Acts 28:6
content: 6 But they were expecting him to begin to be inflamed or suddenly to fall down dead. But as they watched for a long time and saw nothing unusual happening to him, turning themselves around, they said he was a god.

title: Acts 28:7
content: 7 Now in the {areas} around that place were lands of the first of the island, Publius by name, who, welcoming us, kindly entertained us for three days.

title: Acts 28:8
content: 8 And it happened that the father of Publius was lying sick, being afflicted with fevers and dysentery, to whom having gone in and having prayed, having placed {his} hands on him, Paul healed him.

title: Acts 28:9
content: 9 And this having happened, the others on the island having sicknesses were also coming and being healed.

title: Acts 28:10
content: 10 They also honored us with many honors, and they gave to us as we were putting to sea the things for {our} needs.

title: Acts 28:11
content: 11 And after three months, we put to sea in an Alexandrian ship with a Dioscouri figurehead having wintered at the island.

title: Acts 28:12
content: 12 And having come down to Syracuse, we stayed for three days.

title: Acts 28:13
content: 13 Having sailed from there, we came down to Rhegium, and after one day, a south wind having occurred, we came to Puteoli the next day,

title: Acts 28:14
content: 14 where, having found brothers, we were begged to stay with them for seven days, and thus we went towards Rome.

title: Acts 28:15
content: 15 From there, the brothers, having heard the things about us, came to a meeting with us as far as the Forum of Appius and Three Taverns, whom seeing, Paul, thanking God, took courage.

title: Acts 28:16
content: 16 And when we entered into Rome, Paul was allowed to stay by himself with the soldier guarding him.

title: Acts 28:17
content: 17 And it happened that after three days, he called together the ones being first among the Jews. And when they had come together, he said to them, “Men, brothers, having done nothing opposed to the people or to the fathers’ customs, I was delivered as a prisoner from Jerusalem into the hands of the Romans,

title: Acts 28:18
content: 18 who, having questioned me, were intending to release me because there was no reason in me for death.

title: Acts 28:19
content: 19 But as the Jews were objecting, I was forced to appeal to Caesar—not as if having anything {of which} to accuse my nation.

title: Acts 28:20
content: 20 Therefore for this reason I summoned you, to see and to speak with you. For on account of the hope of Israel I am bound with this chain.”

title: Acts 28:21
content: 21 But they said to him, “We have not received letters from Judea about you, nor have any of the brothers, coming, reported or said anything evil about you.

title: Acts 28:22
content: 22 But we value to hear from you what you think, for concerning this sect, it is known to us that it is spoken against everywhere.”

title: Acts 28:23
content: 23 And having appointed a day for him, more came to him at his lodging, to whom he was explaining, testifying about the kingdom of God and persuading them about Jesus both from the Law of Moses and the Prophets from morning until evening.

title: Acts 28:24
content: 24 And while some were convinced by the things being said, others still did not believe.

title: Acts 28:25
content: 25 And being discordant with one another, they were leaving, Paul having spoken one word, “The Holy Spirit spoke well through Isaiah the prophet to your fathers,

title: Acts 28:26
content: 26 saying, ‘Go to this people and say, “By hearing you will hear but you will not understand at all, and seeing you will see but you will not perceive at all.”

title: Acts 28:27
content: 27 For the heart of this people has been thickened, and with {their} ears they have hardly heard, and they have shut their eyes, lest they might see with {their} eyes, and they might hear with {their} ears, and they might understand with {their} heart and turn back, and I would heal them.’

title: Acts 28:28
content: 28 Therefore, let it be known to you that this salvation of God has been sent to the Gentiles, and they will hear.”

title: Acts 28:29
content: 29 [And when he had said these things, the Jews went away, having a great dispute among themselves.]

title: Acts 28:30
content: 30 And he stayed for two whole years in his own rented house, and he was welcoming all the ones coming in to him,

title: Acts 28:31
content: 31 proclaiming the kingdom of God and teaching the things about the Lord Jesus Christ with all boldness, without hindrance.
